intro: Commiphora ruspolii, commonly known as the Somali myrrh tree, is a small to medium-sized evergreen shrub or tree native to the Horn of Africa. It belongs to the Burseraceae family, which includes frankincense and myrrh trees, and is characterized by its aromatic resin-producing capabilities. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and has small, leathery leaves with a glossy surface. Its bark and resin have been used historically for medicinal and aromatic purposes. Commiphora ruspolii is also valued for its ecological role in supporting local biodiversity in arid regions.
